questions.text: Which of the following is used to prevent delayed cererbral ischemia in aneurysmal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nimodipine

 

Explanation:

Nimodipine is used to prevent delayed ischemia in the acute phase of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage management:

Nimodipine

Prevents delayed ischemia in the acute phase of SAH.

Aneurysm Management

-Endovascular coiling

-Surgical clipping

Arteriovenous malformation Management

Surgical removal.

  • Ligation of feeding or draining blood vessels.
  • Injection of material to occlude fistula or draining veins.

Complications Treatment

Obstructive hydrocephalus: May need shunt drainage.

Delayed cerebral ischaemia (vasospasm): Treated with vasodilators.

Hyponatraemia: Managed by fluid restriction.

Systemic complications (immobility): Manage chest infections and venous thrombosis.

 

Nifedipine (Option A): It does not cross the blood-brain barrier effectively and is not used to prevent cerebral vasospasm or delayed ischemia in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

 

Amlodipine (Option B): Long-acting calcium channel blocker used for systemic hypertension and angina. Like nifedipine, it lacks specificity for cerebral vessels and is not effective in preventing delayed cerebral ischemia after SAH.

 

Felodipine (Option D): Dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used in managing hypertension, but it has no proven benefit in preventing cerebral vasospasm or ischemia post-SAH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with poorly localized burning pain in the lower torso and legs. Then he noticed progressive weakness in both arms and legs over the past 3 months, . On neurological examination, there is spasticity and hyperreflexia in both upper and lower limbs, with preserved perianal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely site of pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Intramedullary compression

If the lesion is inside the cord, sensory symptoms (especially burning or poorly localized pain) tend to appear early, whereas if the lesion is outside the cord, motor/root symptoms usually dominate first due to outside-in compression. In this case, the patient presents with sensory symptoms with sacral sparing, which is characteristic of an intramedullary lesion.
The involvement of the spinothalamic tract explains the dysesthesia, and bilateral corticospinal tract involvement points toward a cervical cord location.

Other incorrect options 

a. Extradural compression – Typically causes localized back/radicular pain and asymmetric motor symptoms early due to outside-in compression.

b. Intradural extramedullary – Often presents with root pain, early motor weakness, and dorsal column signs, not burning dysesthesia.

c. Foramen magnum lesion – Would cause spastic quadriparesis but typically includes cranial nerve involvement (e.g., dysphagia, facial symptoms), which is absent here.

 

Intramedullary compression of the spinal cord:

Causes
  1. Tumors: Ependymomas, Astrocytomas, Hemangioblastomas
  2. Abscesss : pyogenic or tuberculous abscesses
  3. Multiple sclerosis:
  4. Trauma
  5. Syringomelia 

Clinical features

Motor Symptoms: Weakness or paralysis in the limbs, typically presenting as bilateral weakness.

Reflex Changes: Hyperreflexia and spasticity below the level of the lesion.

Pain: Poorly localized, burning pain and spared sensation in the perineal and sacral areas(sacral sparing).

Diagnosis

MRI of the Spine: The gold standard for identifying intramedullary lesions.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of radicular pain on the lower back associated with loss of sensations over sacrum and urinary incontinence. There was weakness, started over lower limbs one month back and now weakness is present over upper limbs. What is the ideal imaging of choice to diagnose this condition?

choices.text: X-ray LS spine AP and lateral view

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) MRI

Explanation:

 

Radicular pain with sacral loss + Ascending paralysis + early Bladder involvement is suggestive of extramedullary compression of spinal cord. MRI preferably T2-sequence is the ideal imaging of choice to diagnose spinal pathologies.


 

Extramedullary Compression on Spinal Cord:

Causes
  • Intradural: Benign Neurofibroma; Slow onset of symptoms seen
  • Extradural: Spinal metastases from Breast/lung/Prostate cancer; Relatively rapid onset of manifestations seen

Clinical features
  • Radicular (root) pain along the nerve root involved
  • Early sacral sensory loss
  • Ascending spastic paralysis starting from lower limbs
  • Bladder involvement - early

questions.text: Which among the following is seen in this spinal cord lesion as shown below?

choices.text: C/L loss of vibration sense below the level of lesion
C/L loss of thermal sensation at and above the same level
I/L loss of muscle tone at the level of lesion
C/L loss of pain 2 segments above the level of lesion

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)  I/L loss of muscle tone at the level of lesion

 

Explanation:

Hemisection of the spinal cord/ Brown sequard syndrome results in I/L loss of sensations carried by dorsal and pyramidal column tracts and C/L loss of sensations carried by spinothalamic tract  2 segments below the level of lesion. 

 

Features of Brown-Sequard syndrome/ Hemisection of Spinal Cord

 

Ipsilateral 

Contralateral 

At the level of lesion

LMN paralysis and radicular pain

Dorsal column: Loss of vibration and proprioception

 

Below the level of lesion

CST: UMN paralysis

Dorsal column: Loss of vibration and proprioception

Spinothalamic tract: Loss of Pain and Temperature

questions.text: 30 year old  female presents with complaints of progressive weakness of lower limbs, numbness, difficulty walking and recent onset forgetfulness. On examination, bilateral loss of vibration sense is noted , bilateral ankle jerks are absent with bilateral babinski sign. Romberg sign is present with eyes closed. Peripheral blood smear done was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Subacute combined demyelination of Spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Subacute combined demyelination of Spinal cord

 

Explanation:

This clinical scenario is classic for Subacute Combined Degeneration  due to Vitamin B12 deficiency, which affects both the dorsal columns (causing loss of vibration sense, positive Romberg sign) and the lateral corticospinal tracts (causing weakness and bilateral Babinski sign). The presence of absent ankle jerks with extensor plantar response suggests a mixed UMN and LMN picture seen in SACD as it involves both peripheral nerves and dorsal column. 

Note that neurological features can exist without hematological featuers. 

Incorrect options 

Tabes dorsalis also affects dorsal columns and can cause sensory ataxia, but there is no UMN involvement (Babinski sign would not be present). 
Friedreich’s ataxia has onset in adolescence and has cardiomyopathy, and a family history, which are not mentioned.
Brown-Séquard syndrome presents with  ipsilateral motor and vibration loss with contralateral pain loss not a bilateral symmetrical presentation as seen here.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with sudden symmetrical onset of both lower extremity weakness, numbness, and urinary retention. She reports a history of a respiratory tract infection two weeks ago. Neurological examination reveals reduced muscle strength and sensory loss below the mid-thoracic region, along with hyperreflexia. MRI of the spine shows a focal area of increased T2 signal in the thoracic spinal cord without evidence of compression. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Transverse myelitis

 

Explanation:

Rapid onset B/L symmetrical weakness post-infective sequelae with Hyperintensities within the spinal cord on T2-MRI is suggestive of Transverse Myelitis.

 

Transverse Myelitis:

Introduction
  • Acquired focal inflammatory disorder of spinal cord

Etio- pathogenesis
  • Idiopathic: Most common
  • Post-infectious: Usually Enterovirus, Herpes, HIV
  • Inflammatory/Autoimmune: Ankylosing spondylitis, APLA syndrome, Behcet disease, RA, Scleroderma
  • Multifocal CNS disorders: Multiple sclerosis, Neurosarcoidosis

Clinical features
  • Motor: Sudden onset B/L usually symmetric rapid paralysis initially flaccidity, and later spasticity sets in.
  • Sensory: Pain, Dysaesthesia, Paraesthesia
  • Autonomic: Bowel/bladder disturbances +, impotence +
  • Backache: Corresponding to the level of lesion

Diagnosis
  • T2-MRI: Focal Hyperintense signals within the spinal cord
  • CSF Analysis: To rule out other infectious/inflammatory etiology, elevated IgG index may be present
  • Histopathology: Perivascular infiltration of monocytes/lymphocytes + demyelination +/- axonal injury

Management
  • First line: High dose IV Glucocorticoids
  • Plasmapheresis
  • Other immunomodulators: Cyclophosphamide, Mycophenolate, Rituximab

 

Multiple sclerosis (Option A): MS can present with spinal cord lesions, but typically these are asymmetrical and multifocal. This patient’s rapid, symmetrical onset of symptoms and the absence of other characteristic findings like Optic neuritis, Lhermitte sign, Uhthoff’s phenomenon, MRI shows characteristic Dawson’s fingers and CSF analysis reveals Oligoclonal bands - thereby making MS less likely.

 

Guillain-Barré syndrome (Option B): GBS often presents with ascending asymmetric weakness and areflexia, affecting peripheral nerves. CSF analysis reveals Albumino-cytological dissociation. However, this patient has hyperreflexia and sensory loss in a well-defined spinal cord region, which is more indicative of central nervous system pathology, ruling out GBS.


Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) (Option D): ALS causes progressive motor neuron degeneration, leading to both upper and lower motor neuron signs without sensory deficits. The acute onset, sensory involvement, and bladder dysfunction are not typical of ALS.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with multiple episodes of  involuntary urine passage in clothes, lower back pain and bilateral lower limb weakness. On examination, he has saddle anesthesia, intact knee jerks and absent ankle jerks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Conus medullaris syndrome 

 

Explanation:

The presence of saddle anesthesia, early bladder involvement, bilateral lower limb weakness, and mixed UMN (knee jerk preserved) + LMN (ankle jerk absent) signs point strongly to conus medullaris syndrome. 

incorrect options 
Cauda equina syndrome shows asymmetric LMN signs, severe radicular pain, and late bladder involvement, which is not seen here.
Transverse myelitis usually presents with a clear sensory level, spasticity, and UMN signs, unlike the mixed picture here.
Spinal shock causes flaccid paralysis and areflexia in the acute phase but lacks the saddle anesthesia and early bladder symptoms that define conus medullaris.
Thus, option A (Conus medullaris syndrome) best explains the clinical picture.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in cauda equina syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Brisk bulbocavernosus reflex

 

Explanation:

Brisk bulbocavernosus reflex, which is least likely in cauda equina syndrome  as it a LMN lesion. It occurs due to compression of lumbosacral nerve roots, so reflexes like the bulbocavernosus are reduced or absent. Back pain, saddle anesthesia, and impotence are hallmark features due to sensory and autonomic involvement. A brisk reflex would suggest an UMN lesion, which is not characteristic of CES.

 

Cauda Equina Syndrome:

Definition

Compression and disruption of the nerve roots from the distal spinal cord (typically L1-L5), often resulting from damage (secondary to trauma, tumors, herniated discs, or spinal stenosis ) to L3-L5 nerve roots

Clinical features

 

- Back pain and sciatica (Option A ruled out)

- Bladder dysfunction (retention or incontinence)

- Bowel dysfunction (retention or incontinence)

- Saddle anesthesia (Option B ruled out)

- Sexual dysfunction (impotence in men). (Option D ruled out)

- Motor or sensory deficits in the legs, often asymmetric.

- Lower motor neuron signs: areflexia, hypotonia, atrophy.

- Decreased rectal tone.

- Absent bulbocavernosus reflex (Option C)

Diagnosis

- Urgent MRI with sagittal and axial T1 and T2 sequences is the gold standard.

- CT myelogram for patients contraindicated for MRI.

- Bladder scan to check post-void residual volume for urinary retention.

Management

Surgical decompression (laminectomy, discectomy, or sequestrectomy) with early neurosurgical or orthopedic consultation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about conus medullaris syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Priapism

 

Explanation:

Loss of anal reflex and bilateral saddle anesthesia are hallmark features of conus medullaris syndrome, due to involvement of sacral (S2–S4) nerve roots. Early urinary incontinence occurs from autonomic dysfunction affecting bladder control. These are typical findings in CMS. However, priapism is not seen in conus lesions; it is more characteristic of acute high spinal cord injuries above T6 due to sympathetic disruption. Therefore, option D is the incorrect statement. 

Features 

Symptoms
  • Bilateral saddle anesthesia (S3–S5)involving the perineum, inner thighs, and buttocks.
  • Prominent urinary retention, incontinence, and lax anal tone.
  • Impotence is common due to the involvement of sacral segments.
  • Largely preserved muscle strength 
  • Absent bulbocavernosus reflex (S2–S4) and anal reflex (S4–S5).
  • Typically minimal or absent pain

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness and sensory loss in her arms, along with muscle wasting in her hands. MRI reveals a large intramedullary spinal cord tumor, with an associated syrinx. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tumor resection

 

Explanation:

Tumor resection is preferred in Syrinx secondary to intramedullary spinal cord tumors

 

Syringomyelia:

 

Diagnosis

MRI to detect syrinx cavities, spinal cord enlargement, assess Chiari malformation, and determine hydrocephalus.


 

Treatment
  • Chiari malformation treatment: Suboccipital craniectomy, cervical laminectomy, dural graft placement.
  • Hydrocephalus with Chiari: Shunting precedes syrinx correction.
  • Syrinx secondary to trauma/infection: Decompression and drainage (shunt or fenestration).
  • Syrinx due to intramedullary spinal cord tumors: Tumor resection is preferred.
 

Note: Patients with minimal symptoms do not require surgery and are monitored with clinical and imaging follow-up.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about syringomyelia is wrong?

choices.text: A developmental cavity in the cervical cord
Symptoms begin in adolescence or early adulthood
The majority linked with Chiari type 2 malformation
Sensory loss in a cape distribution

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The majority linked with Chiari type 2 malformation

 

Explanation:

More than half of syringomyelia cases are linked with Chiari type 1 malformations.

 

Syringomyelia:

Definition

A developmental cavity in the cervical cord (Option A ruled out) that can enlarge or remain asymptomatic.

Onset & Progression

Symptoms begin in adolescence or early adulthood (Option B ruled out), progress irregularly, and may undergo spontaneous arrest.

Common Association

More than half of cases are linked with Chiari type 1 malformations (cerebellar tonsils protrude through the foramen magnum and cervical spinal canal). (Option C)

Pathophysiology

Possibly related to interference with CSF flow, particularly due to Chiari malformations.

Presentation

Dissociated sensory loss (pain and temperature loss, touch and vibration spared).

Areflexic weakness in upper limbs.

Suspended sensory loss in a cape distribution (nape, shoulders, upper arms, hands). (Option D ruled out)

Muscle wasting in neck, shoulders, arms, hands; absent/asymmetric reflexes in arms.

As syrinx expands: Spasticity, leg weakness, bladder/bowel dysfunction, Horner's syndrome.

Facial numbness from trigeminal damage (C2 level or above).

Additional Symptoms

Chiari-associated symptoms: Cough-induced headache, neck, arm, or facial pain.

Syringobulbia: Palatal/vocal cord paralysis, dysarthria, nystagmus, vertigo, tongue weakness.

questions.text: Which gene mutation is primarily associated with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) SCN4A

 

Explanation:

Mutations in the SCN4A gene, which encodes a sodium channel, are responsible for hyperkalemic periodic paralysis.

 

KCNJ2 (Option A): Associated with Anderson-Tawil syndrome and hypokalemic periodic paralysis.

 

CACNA1S (Option B): Mutations in this gene are linked to hypokalemic periodic paralysis and other channelopathies.


RYR1 (Option D): Mutations in this gene are associated with malignant hyperthermia and central core disease.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache followed by brief loss of consciousness. NCCT head reveals blood in the basal cisterns. CT angiography shows a ruptured anterior communicating artery aneurysm. She is alert and oriented (Hunt and Hess grade II). BP on admission is 160/100 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment to prevent rebleeding in this patient?

choices.text: Administration of nimodipine to prevent vasospasm
Strict blood pressure control with iv labetalol

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Endovascular coiling of the aneurysm

 

Explanation:

This patient has aneurysmal SAH confirmed on CT angiography. The definitive treatment to prevent rebleeding is securing the aneurysm, and endovascular coiling is the preferred method in most cases, especially in good-grade patients (like Hunt & Hess I–III) or when the aneurysm is accessible via catheter. Clipping is an alternative but more invasive and typically reserved for unfavorable anatomy or failed coiling. Nimodipine is essential to reduce the risk of delayed cerebral ischemia, but it doesn't prevent rebleeding. Blood pressure control is supportive but not definitive therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the ER with a sudden headache described as the "worst headache of their life." A non-contrast head CT is normal. Despite this, the suspicion of subarachnoid hemorrhage remains high. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Repeat the head CT scan in 24 hours
Lumbar puncture to assess for xanthochromia
Perform a Time-of-Flight Magnetic Resonance Angiography (TOF-MRA)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lumbar puncture to assess for xanthochromia

 

Explanation:  Lumbar puncture  to assess for xanthochromia is the next step if the initial CT scan is negative but clinical suspicion for SAH remains high. Ideally, the LP should be performed at least > 6 hours after the headache onset to detect xanthochromia, which indicates blood breakdown in the cerebrospinal fluid 

Repeat CT in 24 hours: No added benefit — bleeding would have been evident initially.

Immediate cerebral angiography: Only indicated after confirming SAH (via CT or LP).

TOF-MRA: Not the diagnostic standard in acute suspected SAH — and again, requires proof of hemorrhage first.

 

Sensitivity Considerations:

  • CT Scans and RBC Counts: Highly sensitive early in diagnosis but decrease over time due to the fast flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). (Option A ruled out)
  • RBC Lysis: RBCs in the CSF break down over time, producing bilirubin and oxyhemoglobin, making xanthochromia more detectable after several hours.

 

Diagnostic Protocols

  • Lumbar Puncture Before Imaging: Only if CT is unavailable.
  • Four-Vessel Conventional X-ray Angiography: Typically performed to localize the aneurysm and check for additional unruptured aneurysms.
  • Endovascular Treatment: In some centers, endovascular techniques are performed during the angiogram to minimize invasive procedures.
  • CT Angiography: An alternative for aneurysm localization and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe headache. On admission, her GCS is 12/15 and non-contrast CT head shows blood in the Sylvian fissure. On day 4 of hospitalization, she becomes increasingly drowsy and develops slow speech. Repeat CT reveals no new hemorrhage or infarct. She has polyuria, and her serum sodium is 125 mEq/L. On examination, she appears dehydrated. What is the most likely cause of her clinical deterioration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cerebral salt-wasting syndrome

 

Explanation:

Hyponatremia occurs in the first two weeks after SAH due to cerebral salt-wasting syndrome, leading to volume depletion and mental status changes, as seen in this patient.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Delayed neurological deficits

Rerupture
  • Incidence: ~30% in the first month, with peak in the first 7 days.
  • Mortality rate: 50%.
  • Prevention: Early treatment eliminates risk.

Hydrocephalus
  • Acute Hydrocephalus: Causes stupor/coma; managed by external ventricular drain.
  • Subacute Hydrocephalus: Develops over days/weeks; causes drowsiness, slowed thinking, and incontinence.
    • Diagnosed via CT, CTA, TCD ultrasound, or x-ray angiography. (Option B ruled out)
  • Chronic Hydrocephalus: Weeks/months after SAH, with symptoms like gait difficulty, incontinence, or cognitive impairment.

Delayed Cerebral Ischemia (DCI)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Cause: Vasospasm of arteries at the brain’s base, causing ischemia and infarction (~30% of patients).
  • Onset: 4–14 days after hemorrhage (peaks at 7 days).
  • Mechanism: Triggered by blood clots/ breakdown products. More surrounding blood increases vasospasm risk.
  • Symptoms: Sudden focal deficits, mental decline, fluctuating symptoms.
  • Detection: X-ray angiography, TCD ultrasound, or CTA.
  • Treatment: CSF drainage, mannitol/ hypertonic saline, hemicraniectomy, moderate hypothermia.

Hyponatremia
  • Onset: Occurs in the first 2 weeks post-SAH due to natriuresis and volume depletion (hyponatremia + hypovolemia).
  • Cause: Involves atrial and brain natriuretic peptides (cerebral salt-wasting syndrome).
  • Treatment: Resolves in 1–2 weeks. Free-water restriction is avoided to reduce stroke risk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset severe headache for past 6 hours  and nuchal rigidity . CTA shows berry aneurysm at posterior communicating artery . Which of the following clinical features is most likely associated with this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Third cranial nerve palsy

 

Explanation:

Third cranial nerve palsy is typically seen with an aneurysm at the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid junction. It presents with symptoms like pupillary dilation, loss of the ipsilateral light reflex, and eye pain.

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Clinical features and features based on location of bleed

Unruptured Aneurysms
  • Typically asymptomatic but may cause cranial nerve or brain parenchyma compression (mass effect).
  • Prodromal Symptoms:
    • Third Cranial Nerve Palsy: Seen with an expanding aneurysm at the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid junction. Symptoms include pupillary dilation, ipsilateral light reflex loss, and eye pain.
 
  • Sixth Nerve Palsy: May suggest an aneurysm in the cavernous sinus. (Option A ruled out)
  • Visual Field Defects: May occur with an aneurysm in the supraclinoid carotid or anterior cerebral artery (ACA). (Option B ruled out)
  • Occipital/ Cervical Pain: Seen with posterior inferior or anterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysms. (Option D ruled out)
  • Eye/Temple Pain: Expanding middle cerebral artery (MCA) aneurysms can cause pain in or behind the eye and temple.

Ruptured Aneurysms
  • Sudden ICP increase: Occurs at the moment of rupture, often causing transient loss of consciousness in nearly 50% of patients.
  • Headache:
    • Excruciating headaches may precede before the rupture, but most patients report severe headache after regaining consciousness.
    • The primary symptom is a sudden severe headache during exertion, often described as "the worst headache of my life".
    • Some cases may present with moderate headache or changes in usual headache patterns.
    • Additional Symptoms: Generalized headache with neck stiffness and vomiting is common.
  • Focal Neurologic Deficits:
    • May occur if the aneurysm bleeds into the brain or subdural space, causing a hematoma.
    • Deficits include: Hemiparesis, aphasia, mental slowness (abulia).
  • Severe Cases: 10% of patients may lose consciousness for several days due to significant bleeding.
  • Sentinel Bleeds: Small, earlier ruptures causing unexplained headache can precede major SAH, signaling imminent hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 25 -year-old female presents to the ER with a sudden onset severe headache with prostration. On examination BP 180/100 mm Hg and  nuchal rigidity is noted . NCCT head shows blood in slyvian fissure. Which is the next best step in managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B: Cerebral angiography 

 

Explanation:

In a diagnosed case of SAH, next investigation done is cerebral angiography. This will help in diagnosis of site of berry rupture and also identify site(s) of any coexistent berry aneurysm on contralateral site. Following angiography endovascular coiling can be done to prevent rebleeding. Lowering of BP will not be required as it will maintain cerebral perfusion. Nimodipine will be given after procedure to prevent delayed cerebral ischemia that occurs due to protective vasospasm.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about Anderson Tawil syndrome?

choices.text: Sodium channelopathy affecting the cardiac conduction system
Potassium channelopathy affecting skeletal muscle and cardiac conduction
Abnormal chloride transport in skeletal and cardiac muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Potassium channelopathy affecting skeletal muscle and cardiac conduction

 

Explanation:

Potassium channelopathy affecting skeletal muscle and cardiac conduction is consistent with Anderson-Tawil syndrome, which is caused by mutations in the KCNJ2 gene.

 

Clinical Features:

The hallmark of Anderson-Tawil syndrome involves a triad of symptoms:

  • Periodic paralysis
  • Ventricular arrhythmias
  • Prolonged QT interval

 

Dysmorphic Features:

  • Craniofacial abnormalities such as a broad forehead, small mandible, low-set ears, and hypertelorism (wide-spaced eyes).
  • Skeletal abnormalities like short stature, scoliosis, and clinodactyly (curvature of fingers), syndactyly.

Treatment:

  • Potassium supplementation (20-30mEq/L): Oral potassium can help alleviate hypokalemic episodes.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (acetazolamide): These are used to prevent episodes of paralysis. They help stabilize muscle membrane potential.
  • Avoidance of triggers: Maintaining stable potassium level, avoiding fasting, and reducing strenuous exercise can help reduce the frequency of attacks.

 

Cardiac Management:

  • Beta-blockers
  • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)
  • Antiarrhythmic drugs (flecainide, amiodarone)

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of generalized muscle weakness, particularly in his legs, after a day of strenuous exercise followed by a high-carbohydrate meal. He reports experiencing similar episodes of muscle weakness in the past, often triggered by exercise or large meals. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient’s acute presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Oral potassium supplementation

 

Explanation:

In most cases of acute hypokalemic periodic paralysis, oral potassium supplementation is preferred as the first-line treatment, especially when the patient's symptoms are not life-threatening and potassium levels are moderately low.

 

Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis (HypoPP): Autosomal dominant mutations in voltage-gated calcium channels (CACNA1S) or sodium channels (SCN4A).

Treatment:

  • The primary goal is to normalize serum potassium levels by administering oral potassium chloride, which is the first-line treatment.
  • Treatment typically begins with incremental doses of oral potassium chloride, starting at 0.5 to 1 mEq/kg.
  • If a patient requires more than 100 mEq of oral potassium, close monitoring of serum potassium levels is essential, and the total oral potassium dose should not exceed 200 mEq within 24 hours of initiating treatment.
  • IV potassium is not typically the first choice of treatment and is reserved for specific situations such as arrhythmias due to hypokalemia, swallowing difficulties, or respiratory muscle paralysis.
  • IV potassium is usually administered with mannitol.
  • Long-term management: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (acetazolamide) or potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone) to reduce the frequency and severity of episodes.

 

Intravenous potassium (Option B): Used in severe cases of hypokalemia or if oral intake is not feasible; faster correction is generally not needed unless symptoms are life-threatening.

 

Acetazolamide (Option C): Used for long-term prevention of episodes, but not for acute treatment.


Beta-blockers (Option D): Not indicated for hypokalemic periodic paralysis, primarily used in arrhythmias or hypertension.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe muscle weakness, primarily in his legs, which started a few hours after consuming a large, carbohydrate-heavy meal following exercise. He reports similar episodes in the past, often triggered by large meals or after rest following physical activity. His vital signs are stable, and he has no respiratory involvement. Blood work reveals a serum potassium level of 2.3 mEq/L. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Sodium channel dysfunction causing an inability to generate action potentials
Potassium channel dysfunction leading to excessive potassium loss
Calcium or sodium channel mutations causing abnormal potassium influx into cells
Excessive release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Calcium or sodium channel mutations causing abnormal potassium influx into cells

 

Explanation:

Hypokalemic periodic paralysis (HypoPP) is typically caused by mutations in the CACNA1S gene - in 80% cases (calcium channels) or the SCN4A gene - in 10% cases (sodium channels), leading to abnormal potassium shifting into cells.

 

Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis (HypoPP)

  • Genetic disorder caused by skeletal muscle ion channel mutation, mainly affecting sodium or calcium channels.
  • The majority of hypoPP cases are hereditary or familial.
  • The familial form of hypoPP is a rare channelopathy resulting from mutations in either the calcium or sodium ion channels, predominantly affecting skeletal muscle cells.

 

Etiopathogenesis:

  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant mutations in voltage-gated calcium channels (CACNA1S) or sodium channels (SCN4A).
  • The most common familial form, type 1 hypoPP, is characterized by a mutation in the dihydropyridine-sensitive skeletal muscle calcium channel gene, CACNA1S. On the other hand, the type 2 familial form of hypoPP is associated with mutations in the voltage-sensitive skeletal muscle sodium channel gene, SCN4A.
  • Mechanism: Abnormal ion channel function leads to impaired muscle cell depolarization and muscle weakness during attacks.
  • Mutation in the calcium channel revealed abnormal sarcolemmal ATP-sensitive K+ (KATP) channel function, with a lack of stimulation by magnesium adenosine diphosphate (MgADP), likely contributing to depolarization during hypokalemia.

 

Triggers:

  • Common triggers: Carbohydrate-rich meals, strenuous exercise followed by rest, stress, and cold exposure.

 

Clinical Features:

  • The mean age of presentation of attacks is the first or second decade of life during teenage or childhood.
  • Episodic weakness: Sudden onset of flaccid paralysis, typically affecting proximal muscles more than distal.
  • Pattern: Weakness usually begins in the legs and progresses to the arms, sparing respiratory and ocular muscles.
  • The pattern of muscle weakness is similar in both familial and thyrotoxic hypoPP, and signs of hyperthyroidism are often evident in most cases of thyrotoxic hypoPP.
  • Hyporeflexia or Areflexia is a common finding.
  • Muscle weakness between attacks that improves with mild exercise.
  • Respiratory muscle involvement in severe cases.

 

Diagnosis:

  • HypoPP is suspected when an individual presents with a sudden attack of flaccid muscle weakness involving proximal muscles, accompanied by either decreased or normal deep tendon reflexes, especially after exposure to known triggering factors.
  • However, without a family history, a low serum potassium level during a typical weakness episode helps establish the diagnosis.
  • Serum potassium levels: Low during attacks (hypokalemia).
  • ECG: May show U waves, prolonged QT interval, or arrhythmias during hypokalemia.
  • Genetic testing: Identifies mutations in the CACNA1S or SCN4A genes.
  • Provocative testing using potassium, insulin, or glucose administration can be used to diagnose hypoPP.
  • EMG techniques such as the exercise test can be employed to assess the change in muscle fiber excitability due to channelopathy.

 

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Anderson-Tawil syndrome
  • Hyperkalemic Periodic Paralysis
  • Thyrotoxic Periodic Paralysis
  • Paramyotonia Congenita

 

Treatment:

  • The primary goal is to normalize serum potassium levels by administering oral potassium chloride which is the first-line treatment.
  • Treatment typically begins with incremental doses of oral potassium chloride, starting at 0.5 to 1 mEq/kg.
  • If a patient requires more than 100 mEq of oral potassium, close monitoring of serum potassium levels is essential, and the total oral potassium dose should not exceed 200 mEq within 24 hours of initiating treatment.
  • IV potassium is not typically the first choice of treatment and is reserved for specific situations such as arrhythmias due to hypokalemia, swallowing difficulties, or respiratory muscle paralysis.
  • IV potassium is usually administered with mannitol.

Long-term management: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (acetazolamide) or potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone) to reduce frequency and severity of episodes.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle stiffness, especially in his face and hands, following exposure to cold weather. He reports that his symptoms worsen with repeated movements and improve with rest. Upon examination, his muscles are stiff but not weak. His symptoms do not improve with warming .What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Paramyotonia Congenita

 

Explanation:

  • Paramyotonia congenita is a sodium channelopathy (SCN4A mutation) characterized by paradoxical myotonia: worsens with activity and cold, not relieved by warming.

  • Myotonic dystrophy shows progressive weakness, distal wasting, cataracts, and symptoms improve with repeated activity ("warm-up phenomenon").

  • Hypokalemic periodic paralysis presents with episodic weakness, not stiffness, often triggered by rest after exertion or high-carb meals.

  • Becker muscular dystrophy involves progressive muscle weakness, especially proximal limbs, without cold sensitivity or stiffness.
